note: practical designs. Source: Kate Clark The industrial revolution • 293 •
title: problem of crossing rivers or valleys while remaining level. Bridge and aqueduct technology was another area of innovation during the late eighteenth century, when engineers devised new methods, including the use of cast iron on the first iron bridge at Ironbridge in Shropshire. The history of these and many of the other great iron structures tends to be dominated by the great engineers who built them

However, it is important to remember the role of the firms they worked with: William Hazeldine, the Coalbrookdale Company and, in the nineteenth century, the Butterley Company and others whose day-to-day experience in using cast iron Figure 16.7 Reconstruction of a coal waggon on a was likely to have been equally important in creating wooden waggon way
